title: Chase bank heloc loans that were washington mutual
question: i asked chase bank for proof that they owned my loan from washington mutual they sent me a copy of my original agreement with washington mutual is that right i thought ide get a copy of transfer but didnt
question_tags: Bankruptcy,Debt,Mortgage lien,Bankruptcy and debt,Property title,Foreclosure,Real estate and bankruptcy,Home mortgage,Real estate,Deed of trust
answers:
I've always thought that Ms. Martin's responses to AVVO question were nonsensical, and this proves it.

Back in 2009, there was a massive run on Washington Mutual (Yes, like in Mary Poppins, except with computers and without the toppens) and the Office of Thrift Supervision seized Washington Mutual and placed it into with the FDIC (Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation).

The FDIC held a secret auction (how do you get in on those things?) and JPMorgan Chase was the winner (if you could call it that). Under the purchase, JPMorgan Chase agreed to purchase and assume the secured debts of Washington Mutual.

I guess you asking Chase Bank for proof that they owned the debt was liking asking for proof that the sun rises in the east every morning.

You likely will not get the assignment paperwork unless you sue them and request it through a lawsuit (for a legitimate reason). You can however check the property records to see if an assignment was recorded on the deed of trust. WAMU went into a bankruptcy of sorts and all the loans were sold through the bk process some went through Wells Fargo then Chase, some went other places. so it was complicated; but a property report from a title company will tell you anything recorded against your property.

If/when push comes to shove they may be able to prove the acquisition, especially if the HELOC was not delinquent when they got it. Don't be over-confident but don't tolerate any funny business either!
